This is so beautiful â¤ loved the support by husband. Here in India(or at least where I delivered) no one is allowed inside a labour room. I had the same problem when I had son, I had a small lip left, they just rolled me over on my side for a few minutes and it worked!!!
I know that ya'll had a choice between oral pills or patoson to get it started. My doctor didn't give me a choice. Went in to get induced at 5:30am, when my doc arrived, about 8-9 o'clock, he gave me the oral pill, which was broke in half and he broke my water at the same time. You usually take the half pills abt every 3 hours. After he did that, he said, "Now you better not keep me here all day". I said, "I'll be in and out of here in no time". Well....the nurse checked me and said that I was only 7 cm, as soon as she walked out of the door, I felt a POP!! I was calling the nurse, my husband(bc he was home with our twins, waiting on his mom to take over.) When I told the nurse, when she finally came, that I was ready. She said," There's no way you can be at 10, I literally just checked and you were 7cm, I said ,"When you stepped out of my door, I felt a pop". She didn't believe me but she checked anyway. The next words out of her mouth was, "don't move, don't push and just wait for the doctor ". Come to find out,  his head was already out,  a nurse was about to deliver my child. She was born at 12:20pm the same day. The last thing I said to my doctor, "I told you that I would be in and out in no time at all". Best pregnancy, best L&D and her first night, she slept ALL NIGHT!!! It felt so good to have a good full night's sleep in 9 months!!!

I love your dynamic... I gave birth two times, both to boys. So congrats! If I see you and especially Matt... It makes me smile how different every woman in labor is processing the experience. I would've punched my boyfriend in the face if he was supporting me like that. Luckily he knew exactly what I needed, which was a little wet towel on my forhead now and then. And for the rest of delivery to keep quiet and let me be. I really have immense respect for all men/women standing beside there women in labor. You have to see us go through pain and also make sure you do what we need, without us being able to tell you what. I needed my own space as Abby probably needed Matt to cheer her on.  I wouldn't trade it for the world: being able to deliver a human being. I loved everything about it. Enjoy your family Matt & Abby. You both did awesome.

Congratulations Abby and Matt!! Thank you for sharing with us. Just thought I'd drop a (different) comment to say you might be overwhelmed with congratulations, differing opinions, and sometimes even toxic positivity over the next several months. I want you to know that it is ALWAYS OKAY to feel NOT OKAY. It's normal to cry and feel like you can't do this. It doesn't mean you love your son any less. Raising a little human while sleep deprived, recovering from birth, trying to figure out nursing/feeding and reorienting your marriage all at the same time is an insane task. If you ever need anyone to talk to as an outlet, hit me up! Love from a fellow young mama to an 8 month old

Congratulations!!! You guys are going to be amazing parents! May God bless your family! ğŸ™ğŸ½ğŸ™ŒğŸ½â¤ï¸  Just wanted to give you guys a little info. Abby induced labor is definitely a little stronger then going into labor on your own. I got my epidural at 3 centimeters and felt so weak for not holding off longer. But what was never told to me was the induced labor actually forces your body into labor so the contractions are much stronger. I was induced with my firstborn and I wasnâ€™t with my other 2 kids. My second I didnâ€™t ask for the epidural until I was 8 centimeters. My last baby I did a water birth which was an amazing experience and didnâ€™t get any medicine during labor. You did a great job and the best reward is your son. What a blessing! Much love to your family! ğŸ’™

You are such a great wife and mom. At no time did you ever snap at Matt, even through the pain. I know love is the best medicine for any pain and it makes it bearable. Never stop encouraging each other, no matter how many years and how many kids have marked your union.   I am crying so much right now. For utter joy for the two of you and your little bundle of joy. And weeping from sadness, because I never got blessed with a strong or present partner to do this with. I had to face my nightmare of this horrible pain alone, with the strangers that were the birthing unit doctors and nurses as my only company.   For every mom that had or has the blessing of having your spouse or partner at your side, comforting, complimenting and encouraging, in birthing and in life, never let them go and never treat them wrong. Love them always and be grateful for the gift that is them. To the women thinking about having children, if your partner won't do this and won't be willing to be there for you, you've got the wrong man. Find the right the right one and he will make you and your children proud.  Matt and Abby, congratulations with all my love and prayers for your new little miracle!

If any first time moms are watching, please know labor doesnâ€™t have to be THIS hard, or long! And all for a very normal Sized baby- barely 8 pounds!  Girl, your contractions were  killer bc of that dang pitocin ! It makes them worse. And totally unnecessary when actual labor starts naturally. The baby was not ready to come at all and so many signs pointed to that! Itâ€™s perfectly normal and safe to be overdue, whether you have a big baby or not. Due dates are just an estimate, they really donâ€™t mean a thing! Laboring on your back is literally the worst position, and makes it harder bc it goes against gravity. And the shakes are from the epidural. Itâ€™s literally adrenaline.  This is not shaming Matt or Abby, as they are first time parents and had no idea. I have been there too.
